NAME: Mary Church Terrell
MAIN QUOTE: "We knock at the bar of justice, asking an equal chance."
CONTEXT TEXT 1: Her parents, formerly enslaved, became wealthy in business and valued education. She was one of the first African-American women to earn a college degree. She taught at the first black public high school and at Wilberforce University.
CONTEXT TEXT 2: She became an activist when a black friend was lynched by a group of white business owners over a business dispute. She advocated for racial equality through social justice and educational reform.
CONTEXT TEXT 3: She campaigned for women’s right to vote. Finding black women excluded, she cofounded the National Association of Colored Women.
CONTEXT TEXT 4: “[I belong] to the only group in this country that has two such huge obstacles to surmount…both sex and race.”
CONTEXT TEXT 5: She cofounded the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People (NAACP) and College Alumnae Club (National Association of University Women).
CONTEXT TEXT 6: After women won the right to vote, she focused on broader civil rights, protesting segregation into her 80s.
CONTEXT TEXT 7: “Lifting as we climb, onward and upward we go…With courage, born of success achieved in the past…we look forward to a future large with promise and hope…we knock at the bar of justice, asking an equal chance.”
IMAGE CREDITS: Library of Congress, Oberlin College Archives, National Archives and Records Administration, Woman’s American Baptist Home Mission Society. Smithsonian National Museum of African American History & Culture, National Association of Colored Women, Delta Sigma Theta, National Archives and Records Administration

NAME: Florynce Kennedy
CONTEXT TEXT 1: Gadfly: A person who annoys or criticizes others to provoke them into action.
CONTEXT TEXT 2: After high school “Flo” opened a hat shop with her sisters. Within a few years she helped organize her first protest, boycotting a Coca Cola bottler that refused to hire black drivers.
CONTEXT IMG 2: Old Photos of Kansas City in 1938 (2).jpg; Old Photos of Kansas City in 1938 (31).jpg
CONTEXT TEXT 3: She graduated from Columbia University but was rejected from the Law School—until she threatened to sue. She was one of the first black women graduates and then started her law practice.
CONTEXT TEXT 4: From the 1960s until her death in 2000, she fought in the courts and on the streets for women’s and civil rights.
CONTEXT TEXT 5:
“If you found a cause for the downtrodden of somebody being abused someplace, by God, Flo Kennedy would be there.” 
—New York Mayor David N. Dinkins
CONTEXT TEXT 6:
“[She is] the biggest, loudest and, indisputably, the rudest mouth on the battleground where feminist activists and radical politics join in mostly common cause.” 
—People
CONTEXT TEXT 7: “A lot of people think I’m crazy…I never stopped to wonder why I’m not like other people. The mystery to me is why more people aren’t like me.”
IMAGE CREDITS: TBC, Pearson Scott Foresman, LIFE, Library of Congress, Harvard University

NAME: Emma González
CONTEXT TEXT 1: She was a typical teenager until February 2018, when 17 students and teachers died in a mass shooting at her high school in Parkland, Florida.
CONTEXT TEXT 2:
Three days after the shooting, she was asked to speak at a gun-control rally. 

“For what seemed like the first time, adults were treating me and my peers as though they cared about what we had to say. I started writing my speech and didn’t stop until I got up to the lectern. I gave it my all. All of my words, my thoughts, my energy, every political fact I knew.” 

She criticized the National Rifle Association and politicians for not tightening gun laws.
CONTEXT TEXT 3: Her speech was broadcast nationally and began trending on Twitter. With other survivors she founded March for Our Lives, pushing for stricter gun laws and registering young voters.
CONTEXT TEXT 4:
A year later, she has over 1.6 million Twitter followers—hundreds of thousands more than the NRA. 

@Emma4Change
CONTEXT TEXT 5: “If we elect the right people and keep moving as fast as we have been, we will change our world for the better.”
IMAGE CREDITS: Congressman Ted Deutch, Formulanone, Voice of America, Barry Stock, Mobilus In Mobili, Ziggyfan23, Jarek Tuszyński, Robb Wilson, Fibonacci Blue, Ted Eytan

NAME: Jeannette Rankin
MAIN QUOTE: “We’re half the people; we should be half the Congress.”
TITLE 1: First woman elected to U.S. Congress
CONTEXT TEXT 1: Growing up on a ranch, she experienced women and men working side by side as equals.
CONTEXT TEXT 2: She went to college and graduate school and campaigned for women’s right to vote at the state level. She then became a national lobbyist.
CONTEXT TEXT 3:
She ran for Congress as a Representative from Montana in 1916—and won. As the only congresswoman, she was the only woman voting to give women the right to vote!

She ran unsuccessfully for Senate in 1918, but later won a second term in the House.
CONTEXT TEXT 4:
“I am deeply conscious of the responsibility resting upon me…” 


“When her name was called the House cheered and rose, so that she had to rise and bow twice…”
—Observer of Jeannette Rankin being sworn in, 1917
CONTEXT TEXT 5:
A pacifist, she did not believe war was a good way to solve conflicts. She was the only member of Congress to vote against U.S. involvement in both World Wars I and II. Her beliefs ended her political career in 1943.

“The original dove in Congress”
CONTEXT TEXT 6: When not serving in public office, she worked for peace and social change—especially for women and children.
CONTEXT TEXT 7:
In her late 80s she led a march on Washington to protest the Vietnam War. When she died, in her 90s, she was considering another run for the House to protest. 

Never married, she left her estate to help “mature, unemployed women workers.”
CONTEXT TEXT 8: “I may be the first woman member of Congress…But I won’t be the last.”
IMAGE CREDITS: Library of Congress, National Archives and Records Administration, U.S. Congress

NAME: Shirley Chisholm
MAIN QUOTE: “If they don’t give you a seat at the table, bring a folding chair.”
TITLE 1: First black woman elected to U.S. Congress
CONTEXT TEXT 1: Born in Brooklyn to immigrant parents, she lived with her grandmother in Barbados while they worked to get their footing. She went to high school and college in Brooklyn, winning prizes for debate.
CONTEXT TEXT 2: She was a preschool teacher and daycare director and earned a graduate degree in early childhood education. She became a consultant to New York City’s Division of Day Care.
CONTEXT TEXT 3:
Ever aware of racial and gender inequality, she joined national advocacy groups. 

She ran for a seat in the New York State Legislature in 1964—and won.
CONTEXT TEXT 4:
She ran for a seat in the U.S. House of Representatives in 1968, campaigning from a sound truck: 

“Ladies and Gentlemen…this is fighting Shirley Chisholm coming through.”

Her opponent argued their district needed “a man’s voice in Washington,” not that of a “little schoolteacher.” She used this to highlight discrimination against women.
CONTEXT TEXT 5:
She was an outspoken advocate for women and minorities, serving seven terms.

“I have no intention of just sitting quietly and observing…I intend to focus attention on the nation’s problems.”
CONTEXT TEXT 6: She was the first black candidate to seek nomination for president of the United States from one of the two major political parties. Despite many odds, she received 10% of the vote.
CONTEXT TEXT 7: “I want to be remembered as a woman…who dared to be a catalyst of change.”

NAME: Women in the 116th U.S. Congress
MAIN QUOTE: “Being a woman in power means knowing it’s O.K. to be fierce.” —Rep. Joni Ernst (Iowa)
CONTEXT TEXT 1:
“It gives me pride to be the woman Speaker of the House of this Congress, which marks 100 years since women won the right to vote, and as we serve with more than 100 women.”

—Rep. Nancy Pelosi (California), first woman to serve as Speaker of the House of Representatives
CONTEXT TEXT 2:
This is the first time more than 100 women have served in Congress. 

Women have been in Congress more than a century, but only in substantial numbers in recent decades. Numbers continue to rise. 

More women and people of color were elected in 2018 than ever before.

Political power is changing.
CONTEXT TEXT 3:
What it means to be a woman in power varies. For some, gender is central. Others say they are not women politicians, but politicians that happen to be women. 

“I’m a wife, a mother, a grandmother, a business owner and a bison farmer. I don’t think my gender defines who I am, but it does add value and perspective to the decisions I make.”
—Rep. Carol Miller (West Virginia)
CONTEXT TEXT 4:
The first women to represent their states
Many of the women elected in 2018—spanning generations—are historic “firsts” in Congress.


Virginia, New Jersey, and Florida also elected first-time women candidates to Congress.
SLIDESHOW TEXT 4a: Sen. Marsha Blackburn is the first woman elected to the Senate from Tennessee. She is one of the first two Republican women serving on the powerful Senate Judiciary Committee.
SLIDESHOW TEXT 4b:
Rep. Jahana Hayes is the first black woman elected to Congress from Connecticut. She was National Teacher of the Year in 2016.

“I’m unhappy with what the government is doing to public education. But I won’t spend time being angry and waiting for someone else to make a change…”
SLIDESHOW TEXT 4c: Rep. Ayanna Pressley is the first black woman elected to Congress from Massachusetts.
SLIDESHOW TEXT 4d: Reps. Sylvia Garcia and Veronica Escobar are the first Latina women elected to Congress from Texas. Latinos are nearly 40% of the state’s population.
SLIDESHOW TEXT 4e: Sen. Cindy Hyde-Smith is the first woman elected to Congress from Mississippi. In 2019 Vermont is now the only state that has never elected a woman to the Senate or House.
SLIDESHOW TEXT 4f: Sens. Kyrsten Sinema and Martha McSally are the first women elected to the Senate from Arizona.
SLIDESHOW TEXT 4g: Reps. Abby Finkenauer and Cindy Axne are the first women elected to Congress from Iowa. Finkenauer, 29 when she won her seat, is also one of the two youngest women ever elected to Congress.
CONTEXT TEXT 5:
The first Native American women

A record number of Native American people won federal, state, and local offices in 2018.
SLIDESHOW TEXT 5a:
Rep. Deb Haaland, part of the Pueblo of Laguna, was elected to the House from New Mexico.

“Congress has never heard a voice like mine. After years of seeing my community at the whim of national politics while organizing in Indian Country, it was time for me to take the lead.”
SLIDESHOW TEXT 5b:
Rep. Sharice Davids, member of the Ho-Chunk Nation, was elected to the House from Kansas. 

“We have the opportunity to reset expectations about what people think when they think of Kansas…We know there are so many of us who welcome everyone, who see everyone and who know that everyone should have the opportunity to succeed.”
SLIDESHOW TEXT 6a:
Rep. Ilhan Omar, a Somali-American, was elected to the House from Minnesota. She came to the U.S. as a refugee.

“The disconnect between the America I heard about in the refugee camp, a land of opportunity where everyone had an equal shot at a better life, compared to the one I found has motivated me since the first day I arrived.”
SLIDESHOW TEXT 6B: Rep. Rashida Tlaib, daughter of Palestinian immigrants, was elected to the House from Michigan.
CONTEXT TEXT 7:
The youngest women

Rep. Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez, 29 when she won her seat, was elected to the House from New York. (Rep. Abby Finkenauer from Iowa was also 29 when she won her seat.)
CONTEXT TEXT 8:
Congress is also becoming more family friendly. Many congresswomen are mothers of younger children.

“To truly represent the American people, Congress needs more women and moms. I’m expecting my third baby since I was elected to serve, and it is a privilege to offer my unique perspective as we shape policy for all American families.”
—Rep. Jaime Herrera Beutler (Washington)
CONTEXT TEXT 9: Congress is closer to reflecting the American population than it ever was before. More women and people of color in elective office is changing public perception of what political power can look like.
IMAGE CREDITS: Library of Congress, U.S. Congress, American Federation of Government Employees, Gage Skidmore, Phil Roeder, Tony Webster, Speaker of the House

NAME: Alva Belmont
MAIN QUOTE: "The blazing of the trail…is never an easy task."
CONTEXT TEXT 1:
Alva Erskine Smith was born in Alabama. Her father was a cotton merchant and her mother was the daughter of a U.S. Congressman. Her family moved to New York City before the Civil War broke out. 

She attended school in New York and Europe.
CONTEXT TEXT 2:
She married into the wealthy Vanderbilt family in 1875. Twenty years later she divorced her husband and received a large financial settlement. Then she married into another wealthy family, the Belmonts.

“First marry for money, then marry for love.”
CONTEXT TEXT 3: When Mr. Belmont died in 1908, leaving her a rich, powerful widow, she turned her attention to women’s rights. She encouraged women to publicize their cause through parades and mass meetings.
CONTEXT TEXT 4: She held a series of suffrage lectures at her “cottage” in Newport, Rhode Island.
CONTEXT TEXT 5: To help bring working women into the suffrage movement, she raised money and supported 20,000 garment workers on strike.
CONTEXT TEXT 6:
When the leaders of one organization found her too radical, she joined another. She contributed her time, celebrity, and hundreds of thousands of dollars to the campaign for women’s right to vote.

“Someone must pay the price in criticism, even in ostracism, for every advance which the world makes.”
CONTEXT TEXT 7: After women won the right to vote here, she worked for women’s rights in France. When she died, she left $100,000 to the National Woman’s Party. Its headquarters in Washington, DC, is named, in part, for her.
CONTEXT TEXT 8: “Today the world holds up its hands in horror over something which tomorrow it will have to accept as an established fact.”

NAME: Indra Nooyi
TITLE 2: one of the world’s most powerful women
CONTEXT TEXT 1: Born in India, she played cricket and was in an all-girl rock band. After college she earned an M.B.A. and began her career as a product manager for large corporations like Johnson & Johnson.
CONTEXT TEXT 2: She came to the United States and earned a master’s in 1980 from Yale School of Management. After consulting several years, she worked her way up in corporate strategy at multinational companies like Motorola.
CONTEXT TEXT 3:
She joined PepsiCo in 1994 and became its first woman chair and CEO in 2006. Stepping down in 2018, she had held the position for 12 years—7 years longer than average for large companies. 

While increasing profit, she redirected the company toward healthier options. She was chief architect of Performance with Purpose, encouraging PepsiCo to do what’s right for the business by being responsive to the needs of the world.

“Companies like ours are little republics…bigger than many countries…”

“My most ardent hope is that…the most successful companies of tomorrow will do more than make money.”
CONTEXT TEXT 4: She was listed as one of the world’s most powerful women by Forbes, Fortune, Time, The Wall Street Journal, U.S. News & World Report, and CEOWORLD Magazine.
CONTEXT TEXT 5:
She is open about the challenges she experienced raising a family and running a Fortune 500 company. But she also acknowledged that understanding this conflict is the first step to finding solutions and building a network of support. 

“Make the most of your days…”
CONTEXT TEXT 6: She now serves on the board of directors of Amazon (as of 2019). In 2016 she made a large gift to Yale, becoming the first woman to endow a deanship at a top business school.
CONTEXT TEXT 7: “Always have a clear, compelling vision for what you want to accomplish.”
IMAGE CREDITS: Michael Wuertenberg, Jolly Janner, Library of Congress, World Economic Forum, PepsiCo, Government of India, Andy Mettler, World Economic Forum, Nick Allen, GPA Photo Archive

NAME: Arlan Hamilton
MAIN QUOTE: “We’re moving the needle on getting more capital…to underrepresented founders and their companies…”
CONTEXT TEXT 1:
Raised in Dallas, she was taught by her mother that she could be anything she wanted. She followed her dream to work on concert tours. She also started an indie magazine.

“The path to being a venture capitalist has not been a straight one. I didn’t set out or imagine that I would ever be a venture capitalist.”
CONTEXT TEXT 2: She heard about people in the entertainment world investing in Silicon Valley. Always asking questions, she educated herself about venture capital and startups.
CONTEXT TEXT 3: “It was crazy to me that 90% of venture funding was going to white men, when that is not how innovation, intelligence, and drive is dispersed in the real world…I had no background in finance, but I just saw it as a problem. Maybe it’s because I was coming from such a different place that I could recognize it.”
CONTEXT TEXT 4:
She bought a one-way ticket to San Francisco in 2015. With no money or connections, she pursued investors by day and slept on the airport floor at night. She had one goal:

“I wanted to try to get more funding to underrepresented founders…”
CONTEXT TEXT 5:
Her first check, $25,000, came from a woman who believed in her vision. She started Backstage Capital—dedicated to minimizing funding disparities in tech by investing in underestimated founders. More funding followed. 

“I’m a venture capitalist, which means I invest high net-worth individuals’ money into early-stage start-up companies…”
CONTEXT TEXT 6:
Backstage has invested $5 million in 100 startups, from beauty products to business analytics. At least one founder in every company is a woman, person of color, or someone who identifies as LGBT.

She cofounded Backstage Studio in 2018, launching accelerators to boost early-stage startups in four cities, including Philadelphia.
CONTEXT TEXT 7:
She recalled some advice from a fellow VC:

“He said I need to be better than everyone in order to be seen as an equal…It’s very unfair.

But he can ship it to me; I’m not signing for it. I don’t feel the pressure.”
IMAGE CREDITS: William Murphy, David Monniaux, Stuart Isett/Fortune, Angelo DeSantis, Echoing Green Fellows & Programs

NAME: Grace Hopper
MAIN QUOTE: “If you’ve got a good idea…DO IT.”
CONTEXT TEXT 1: Born in New York City, she took clocks apart as a child to see how they worked.
CONTEXT TEXT 2: After graduating from Vassar College, she joined the faculty. She continued studies at Yale University and was one of few people to earn a doctorate in Mathematics in 1934.
CONTEXT TEXT 3: During World War II she joined the WAVES—Women Accepted for Volunteer Emergency Service.
CONTEXT TEXT 4:
First in her officer-training class, she was assigned to the Navy’s Computation Project at Harvard University. Here she became one of the first programmers of the first programmable computer in the country. 

After the War she was a research fellow at Harvard and produced the first programming textbook.
CONTEXT IMG 4: GraceHopper.jpg; Mark I -- The Crew_600ppi.tif; CruftLaboratory1940s.jpg
CONTEXT TEXT 5:
She envisioned people would one day use computers in everyday life. Risking her career, she joined the corporate world in 1949 and helped develop the first commercial computer, UNIVAC. 

She also invented the compiler, which translates instructions into code that computers can read. 

And she codeveloped one of the first computer languages, COBOL.
CONTEXT TEXT 6:
She encouraged programmers to share common portions of programs for efficiency.

She believed change was good and hated hearing, “because we’ve always done it this way.”

To make her point, she had a clock that ran counterclockwise.
CONTEXT IMG 7: She lectured widely, giving up to 300 talks a year!
CONTEXT TEXT 8:
“Amazing Grace” was called back to military service in 1967. There she continued computer work and rose up the ranks to Rear Admiral. Before she retired in 1986, she was the oldest active-duty officer in the country. 

She returned to teaching—her greatest joy—and was a computer consultant into her 80s.
CONTEXT TEXT 9: “I’ve always been more interested in the future than in the past.”
IMAGE CREDITS: United States Navy, Library of Congress, National Museum of American History, Smithsonian Institution, Collection of Historical Scientific Instruments, Harvard University, Harvard University Archives, Mike Gifford, Naval History and Heritage Command

NAME: Reshma Saujani
TITLE 1: Founder and CEO of Girls Who Code
CONTEXT TEXT 1: Born in Illinois, she graduated from the University of Illinois, Harvard Kennedy School (of Government), and Yale Law School.
CONTEXT TEXT 2: She began her career as a lawyer and activist. She also served as deputy public advocate of New York City, an office linking the people with city government—a watchdog for the people.
CONTEXT TEXT 3: In 2010 she became the first Indian-American woman to run for U.S. Congress.
CONTEXT TEXT 4: She did not win. But on the campaign trail, she visited local schools and noticed the gender gap in computer classes. It has been getting worse since the 1990s.
CONTEXT TEXT 5:
To help close this gap, she started Girls Who Code whose mission is:

“…to change the image of what a programmer looks like and does. We’re building the largest pipeline of future female engineers in the United States.”
	[from GWC website]

The national nonprofit equips girls to pursue 21st-century opportunities in technology. The movement is reaching millions through special programs and a bestselling book series. Alumni are majoring in computer-related fields at 15 times the national average.
CONTEXT TEXT 6:
She has also written three books. In Women Who Don’t Wait in Line, she encourages women’s leadership, risk and failure, mentorship and sponsorship, and charting your own course. 

“I’ve chosen opportunities where I might fail rather than live in the shadow of my own potential.”
CONTEXT TEXT 7: She serves on the board of She Should Run, promoting women in public leadership, and the International Rescue Committee, aiding refugees.
IMAGE CREDITS: Nick Allen, PENG Yanan, Alec Perkins, Women’s eNews, Gov. Tom Wolf, City of St. Pete, Fortune

NAME: Sabrina Gonzalez Pasterski
CONTEXT TEXT 1:
Born and raised in Chicago, she is “a proud first-generation Cuban-American.” She attended Edison Regional Gifted Center, a Chicago public school. 

She started flying along the lakefront when she was 9, inspired by a 14-year-old pilot on the Late Show.
CONTEXT TEXT 2: Her grandfather gave her an old airplane for her 10th birthday. She found used parts on eBay and practiced rebuilding an engine outside her bedroom.
CONTEXT TEXT 3: When she was 11, she bought 10 acres of land for $2,000 in West Texas—part of Jeff Bezos’s spaceport—in hopes of one day working for his aerospace company, Blue Origin.
CONTEXT TEXT 4: At 12 she built a kit aircraft engine. The next two years she completed the airframe. Her father—a lawyer/engineer who earned a pilot’s license—flew it in 2008. Thus she was a Light Sport Aircraft Manufacturer at 14.
CONTEXT TEXT 5:
Her first solo flight, in Canada, was hours before her 14th birthday. The same day, she received a job offer from Jeff Bezos. 

She had to wait until 16 before soloing in the United States, in 2009—before she earned a driver’s license.

“Although boys younger than I have built aircraft before me, none were allowed to fly their first U.S. solo in that same craft…It was simply amazing.”
CONTEXT TEXT 6: She graduated from the Illinois Mathematics and Science Academy with a 4.0 GPA in 2010.
CONTEXT TEXT 7:
Initially rejected by MIT and Harvard, she moved to the Boston area because a Nobel Laureate offered her a position as lab assistant or patent clerk. But she was soon admitted to MIT, where she graduated number one in the Physics department and tied for the top overall GPA: 5.00. 

She earned a doctorate from Harvard in 2019.
CONTEXT TEXT 8:
A theoretical physicist who studies high-energy physics, she describes one skill as:

“Spotting the elegance within the chaos.” 

In 2019 she is a principal investigator at the Princeton Center for Theoretical Science.
CONTEXT TEXT 9: She gives talks around the world and has received international recognition for her work promoting STEM education for girls.
IMAGE CREDITS: Cambridge02138, Marc Buehler, Kaboldy, NASA, Cambridge02138, International Monetary Fund

NAME: Ida B. Wells
CONTEXT TEXT 1:
She was born into slavery in Mississippi during the Civil War. Free after the War, her parents were politically active, focusing on education.

“Our job was to go to school and learn all we could.”

Her father helped start Shaw University—now Rust College, one of the first historically black colleges.
CONTEXT TEXT 2:
When she was 16, her parents died of yellow fever. To care for five siblings, she found work as a teacher. She also attended Shaw, but she was expelled over a conflict with the president.

A few years later she moved her family to Tennessee, where she continued teaching.
CONTEXT TEXT 3:
In 1884, at 22, she refused to give up a train seat she paid for when a white conductor asked her to move to the lower-class “black” car.

After being ejected, she sued the Railroad—and won. A higher court reversed the decision. Frustrated, she began writing about race and politics.
CONTEXT TEXT 4:
She saved up and became co-owner of a local black newspaper, writing about injustices. When she called out Memphis for underfunding black schools in 1891 (like the one where she worked), she was fired from teaching.

She became a full-time journalist, writing about racism, sexism, and violence. 

“The people must know before they can act, and there is no educator to compare with the press.”
CONTEXT TEXT 5:
In 1892 three black friends were lynched—killed by a mob, usually by hanging—after defending their store against an attack. Outraged, she wrote an expose on white mob violence. In response, a white mob destroyed her office and threatened her life.

She continued her anti-lynching campaign in New York and Europe, and then moved to Chicago.
CONTEXT TEXT 6:
She married a well-known lawyer (founder of Chicago’s first black newspaper). They had children, and she balanced motherhood and activism. She was one of the first American women to keep her maiden name.

She cofounded the National Association of Colored Women in 1896 and helped start the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People (NAACP) in 1909.
CONTEXT TEXT 7:
She also fought for women’s right to vote. Confronting white women who ignored lynching, she was excluded from their organizations. She founded the first black women’s suffrage club, helping Illinois women get the vote in 1913.

Organizers invited her to march in the 1913 Suffrage Parade in Washington, DC. They asked women of color to march at the back, but she refused. She marched with her state.
CONTEXT TEXT 8: For the rest of her life she was a brave, outspoken advocate for civil rights and women’s rights, through writing and public speaking.
CONTEXT TEXT 9: At 68 she ran for the Illinois legislature, becoming one of the first black women in the country to run for public office (she did not win). She died the next year.
CONTEXT TEXT 10: “The way to right wrongs is to turn the light of truth upon them.”
IMAGE CREDITS: National Portrait Gallery, Ser Amantio di Nicolao, Library of Congress, Internet Archive

NAME: Gloria Steinem
CONTEXT TEXT 1:
Born in Ohio, she was the granddaughter of a well-known suffragist. Her father sold antiques from their mobile home in winter and ran a beach resort in summer. 

Her parents divorced when she was 10, and she helped care for her mother, who was mentally ill. She went to Smith College and studied government, graduating in 1956.
CONTEXT TEXT 2: On a fellowship to India, she developed an interest in Gandhi and grassroots activism. Back in Boston she earned the first Doctorate of Human Justice awarded by Simmons College.
CONTEXT TEXT 3:
She began her career as a freelance journalist in New York. Inevitably, her assignments were lifestyle or fashion pieces for “women’s pages” in the 1950s and 1960s.

“When I suggested political stories to The New York Times Sunday Magazine, my editor just said something like, ‘I don’t think of you that way.’”
CONTEXT TEXT 4: In 1968 she cofounded New York magazine. She covered political campaigns and social issues—including the women’s movement. She began speaking at protests.
CONTEXT TEXT 5: Magazines like Ladies Home Journal only focused on housekeeping. So she cofounded Ms. for the women’s movement in 1971. She was an editor and contributor for the next 15 years—and remains involved.
CONTEXT TEXT 6:
As a freelance writer she has published many articles and several books. She has received numerous awards for journalism and activism, as well as multiple honorary degrees.

She was inducted into the National Women’s Hall of Fame in 1993. President Obama awarded her the Presidential Medal of Freedom, the highest civilian honor.
CONTEXT TEXT 7: She coproduced a documentary on child abuse for HBO, a film about the death penalty for Lifetime, and a documentary series on violence against women for VICE. She is the subject of multiple TV documentaries.
CONTEXT TEXT 8:
In her prolific career she cofounded multiple women’s organizations, including the National Women’s Political Caucus in 1971, Ms. Foundation for Women in 1973 (one of the first and largest women’s funds in the country), and Women’s Media Center in 2004. 

She has dedicated her life to women’s rights—leading marches and touring widely as a public speaker.
IMAGE CREDITS: Library of Congress, Jolly Janner, SAS Scandinavian Airlines, Rob Croes, Liberty Media for Women, LLC, Lynn Gilbert, U.S. Embassy New Zealand, Kristine

NAME: Brittney C. Cooper
MAIN QUOTE: “Tell the whole ugly truth, even when it is inconvenient.”
CONTEXT TEXT 1:
A Louisiana native, she considers herself a small-town Southern girl at heart.

She earned a B.A. in English and Political Science from Howard University, a historically black university in Washington, DC. 

She then pursued a master’s and doctorate in American Studies (and a Women’s Studies Certificate) from Emory University in Atlanta.
CONTEXT TEXT 2: In 2009 she began teaching at the University of Alabama, in the Department of Gender and Race Studies. She then became a postdoctoral fellow at the Center for Race and Ethnicity at Rutgers in New Jersey.
CONTEXT TEXT 3:
In 2019 she is an associate professor at Rutgers, in the departments of Women’s & Gender Studies and Africana Studies. Her research relates to black women’s intellectual history, race and gender in popular culture, and new media. 

She teaches courses such as Black Feminist Thought; Hip Hop: The Birth and Evolution; and Hip Hop Generation Feminism.
CONTEXT TEXT 4:
In 2010 she cofounded Crunk Feminist Collective. (Crunk music is a Southern subgenre of hip hop.)

Blogging as “Crunktastic,” she is known for her posts about gender politics in the hip hop generation, faith and feminism, dating while feminist, and contemporary feminist movements.
CONTEXT TEXT 5:
The feminist-of-color scholar-activist group also does speaking tours, conducts workshops, and engages in activism related to women’s issues.

She coedited The Crunk Feminist Collection, published by The Feminist Press in 2017.
CONTEXT TEXT 6:
She has written two books related to black feminist thought, and contributed to Cosmopolitan.com, Salon.com, and Ms. magazine. Numerous media outlets have featured her social commentary. 

She also studies and writes about historical black women’s organizations as sources of intellectual thought.
CONTEXT TEXT 7: She has received awards for writing, activism, and teaching. In 2016 she won the Olga Vives Award from the National Organization for Women (NOW).
CONTEXT TEXT 8: She thinks black feminism can change the world for the better.
IMAGE CREDITS: University of Memphis, Library of Congress, TED Conference

NAME: Bernice Sandler
CONTEXT TEXT 1: “Bunny” was born and raised in Brooklyn. Her parents owned a clothing store. In school, it annoyed her that girls were not allowed to do things boys could, like be crossing guard, fill inkwells, or work the slide projector.
CONTEXT TEXT 2:
She earned a bachelor’s and master’s in Psychology, and doctorate in Education in 1969. She taught part-time at the University of Maryland. 

Interviewing for a full-time job, she was told by one man, “you come on too strong for a woman.” Another complained women stayed home with sick children. Another said she was “just a housewife who went back to school.”
CONTEXT TEXT 3:
There were no laws against sex discrimination in education.

And she had not considered herself a feminist. (Her husband first defined the rejection as sex discrimination.)

“Like many women at that time…I was somewhat ambivalent about the women’s movement and halfway believed the press descriptions of its supporters as ‘abrasive,’ ‘man-hating,’ ‘radical,’ and ‘unfeminine.’”

But she started researching—and found an executive order outlawing sex discrimination by organizations with federal government contracts. She knew universities received federal money.
CONTEXT TEXT 4:
She initiated a class-action complaint in 1970, charging colleges and universities with an “industrywide pattern” of discrimination.

Working with allies, her efforts became the basis of Title IX (Nine) of the Education Amendments of 1972. Title IX outlawed sex discrimination in federally funded schools.

“She had many allies, but Bunny Sandler was the point person…She taught us that you could actually do something about discrimination.”
—Marty Langelan, sexual harassment expert and friend
CONTEXT TEXT 5:
Title IX opened doors and established protection for women. Today it applies to 16,500 school districts and 7,000 other institutions.

“Every woman who has gone to college, gotten a law degree or a medical degree, was able to take shop instead of home-ec, or went to a military academy really owes her a huge debt…”
—Margaret Dunkle, research colleague and friend
CONTEXT TEXT 6:
She used Title IX to fight sex discrimination in different areas, from employment to sexual harassment to extracurricular activities.

“Title IX turned out to be the legislative equivalent of a Swiss Army knife…It opened up opportunities in so many areas we didn’t foresee, and Bunny laid the essential groundwork for it all…”
—Marty Langelan, sexual harassment expert and friend
CONTEXT TEXT 7:
Title IX is widely associated with gender equality in sports.

Requiring equal access to resources, it transformed college athletics, dramatically increasing the number of women able to play sports.

At the high school level, before Title IX only 4% of girls played, compared to 40% today.
CONTEXT TEXT 8:
She initially thought:

“…it would only take a year or two for all the inequities based on sex to be eliminated.”

She finally realized true change:

“…would take more than my lifetime to accomplish.”
CONTEXT TEXT 9:
She spent the rest of her life fighting sex discrimination in education. She was also an adjunct professor at Drexel University College of Medicine.

As an expert she gave 2,500 presentations, wrote 100 articles and several books, and consulted for numerous institutions (including the military college the Citadel, with its “female assimilation plan”). 

She served on 30 boards, and received a dozen honorary degrees and numerous other awards. She was inducted into the National Women’ Hall of Fame in 2013.
CONTEXT TEXT 10:
She died of cancer in 2019, at age 90. 

Women and men, she said:

“…are far closer to equal than they have ever been in the history of the world…We have only taken the very first steps of what will be a very long journey.”
IMAGE CREDITS: Institute for Women’s Health & Leadership, Drexel University College of Medicine, Rep. John Delaney, Devon Christopher Adams, National Archives and Records Administration (Gerald R. Ford Presidential Library)

NAME: Dawn Staley
MAIN QUOTE: “The journey is incredibly hard…don’t let your foot off the gas, keep going…”
CONTEXT TEXT 1: A North Philadelphia native, she played basketball at Dobbins Technical High School and stood out in the Philadelphia Public League.
CONTEXT TEXT 2:
After high school she played point guard for the University of Virginia, where she earned a B.A. in communications. An “undersized sparkplug,” she led her team to four national tournaments in four years. She won national Player of the Year awards as a junior and senior in 1991 and 1992.

Simultaneously she began her national career on the 1989 Junior World Championship Team. (With a 95% winning record, she played on USA teams nearly every year through 2004.)
CONTEXT TEXT 3: In the mid-1990s she was a pioneer of women’s professional basketball. She played in the ABL for two years and WNBA for eight, appearing in seven All-Star Games. Fans voted her one of the top 15 players in WNBA history.
CONTEXT TEXT 4: Her first Olympics were in 1996, when her team was undefeated, won gold, and was the U.S. committee’s Team of the Year. She also won gold in 2000 and 2004. In Athens in 2004, she carried the flag, leading Team USA in the opening ceremony. She was USA Basketball Female Athlete of the Year in 1994 and 2004.
CONTEXT TEXT 5: She began her coaching career as head coach at Temple University in 2000. In her first season she turned the program around, leading the team to six national tournaments in eight years.
CONTEXT TEXT 6:
Since 2008 she has been head coach at the University of South Carolina. Her team won the national championship in 2017. 

During the tournament, the first African-American woman to win the title (Carolyn Peck) gave her a piece of the net from that championship, reminding her she had:

“…a real good shot at winning. Sometimes you need something tangible to hold onto to let you know that somebody did it before you…”
CONTEXT TEXT 7: In addition she began her national coaching career in 2006 and was assistant coach of the team that won Olympic gold in 2008 and 2016. She is head coach of the 2017–20 team, qualified for the Tokyo 2020 Summer Olympics.
CONTEXT TEXT 8: She is the first person to receive both the USA Basketball National Coach of the Year and Athlete of the Year awards. She has received multiple Coach of the Year awards and was inducted into the Women’s Basketball Hall of Fame in 2012.
CONTEXT TEXT 9: She is known for her work with children in need, setting up charitable foundations. The WNBA established the Dawn Staley Community Leadership Award in 2007, awarded to players who best exemplify leadership in their communities.
CONTEXT TEXT 10:
She seeks to provide hope to young athletes:

“If they’re faced with roadblocks along the way, I want them to look at me with our national championship and say, that is what I need to get me through this particular moment.”
IMAGE CREDITS: Sphilbrick, chrisinphilly5448, Alterego, Emilio Garcia, Leslie, South Carolina Office of the Governor, Kris Krüg, Philadelphia City Council

NAME: Mo’ne Davis
MAIN QUOTE: “I throw 70 miles an hour. That’s throwing like a girl.”
TITLE 1: First girl to pitch a shutout in the Little League World Series
CONTEXT TEXT 1:
The coach at her local recreation center in South Philadelphia saw her playing football with her older brother and cousins when she was 10.

“There she was throwing this football in perfect spirals, effortless and running these tough kids down and tackling them…”
	—Steve Bandura, coach

He invited her to basketball practice. 

“Her eyes were just glued on the drill and when it came time for her turn she went through it like she has been doing it a thousand times…I just knew right then.”
CONTEXT TEXT 2:
The only girl, she became the team’s best player, dominating the game in basketball, baseball, and soccer—and helping win city championships.

Showing dedication, she got up early to commute to an all-girls private school in Chestnut Hill and went to the rec center after school for practice or games.
CONTEXT TEXT 3:
In 2014 she became the first girl to pitch a shutout in the Little League World Series in Williamsport, PA. She threw a 70 mph fastball, at 13.

She was the fourth American girl (18th overall) to play in the tournament, out of 9,000 participants since it began in 1947.
CONTEXT TEXT 4: Before 8th grade she had pitched before a TV audience of millions and was on the cover of Sports Illustrated.
CONTEXT TEXT 5:
The Obamas invited her to the White House, inspiring her: 

“You changed the sports world. Keep going. Don’t let anyone stop you.”

The attention was overwhelming.

“I was a kid; I wasn’t prepared for this.” 

She was also the first African-American girl in the Little League World Series.

“She’s a novelty in the white community, a celebrity you want to take a picture with, but in the black community, she’s more of a cultural icon…Little League baseball is a white suburban sport. Mo’ne is an African-American girl. She crossed every barrier.”
—Steve Bandura, coach
CONTEXT TEXT 6:
After the tournament, a college player (a young man) wrote a belittling, sexist tweet about her. He was suspended for the season, but she asked for him to be allowed back.

“Everyone makes mistakes and everyone deserves a second chance.”

“This world is already full of hate. You can’t just keep putting hate out there.”
CONTEXT TEXT 7:
In 2015 she took a trip with her team, playing baseball and exploring black history. On her 14th birthday, the team visited the Alabama church where white supremacists killed four black girls in 1963.

“We walked past where the bomb was placed; I still don’t have words for it…What could those girls have done in their lives? They could have changed the world.”

The experience left her grateful:

“…for all the people who fought for the freedom we now have.”
CONTEXT TEXT 8:
In high school she played as many sports as she could, winning state championships in softball and soccer. Summers she continued pitching, and her baseball team won a national championship in 2017.

Her friends call her “Big Time” and “Superstar.” But:

“She’s not one of these people who’s like, ‘I’m already famous so I don’t have to work hard.’ She always picked up everyone’s mood. She brought a happy spirit to the team.”
—Emily McNesby, soccer teammate

She would call her coach to discuss ways to improve, and she always credited teammates and encouraged younger players.
CONTEXT TEXT 9:
Graduating in 2019, she has committed to playing softball at Hampton University in Virginia. Her high school experiences and older friends influenced her decision to attend a historically black university.

Planning to major in communications, she wants to be a motivational speaker for kids and host her own TV sports show.
IMAGE CREDITS: Sam Nabi, U.S. Department of the Interior, Walt Disney Television, Library of Congress, Philadelphia City Council, Douglas W. Reynolds
